Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Scalable Kilo-Pixel Detector Modules Based on Polarization Sensitive Multi-Chroic Aluminum Manganese MKIDs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The cosmic microwave background is an image of the Universe in its infancy. It spans the entire sky, but it is only visible to detectors that are sensitive to microwaves. Understanding this background with ever-greater precision led to our current understanding of cosmology. Further advances require more sensitive and precise detectors. Johnson and collaborators are developing a novel, potentially transformative technology called Microwave Kinetic Inductance Detectors (MKIDs). Such devices have a superconducting film that is especially sensitive to light. The devices are also sensitive to polarization, which enables them to make further scientific discoveries. MKIDs can be scaled to large arrays, which are needed for precise observations. Johnson and collaborators will create MKIDs using a new material -- manganese doped aluminum. They will build an improved prototype detector with more than ten times the number of pixels and demonstrate its sensitivity and scalability.

This project will develop kilo-pixel arrays of polarization-sensitive Microwave Kinetic Inductance Detectors (MKIDs) that are sensitive to submillimeter radiation in the range 130-280 GHz. MKIDs operate by using superconducting resonators whose resonant frequency changes when incident photons break Cooper pairs in the device. Changes in resonance are monitored by a probe tone that drives the resonator. Each detector can have a unique resonance, which enables multiplexing many pixels onto a single output signal. Such multiplexing may enable very large arrays of detectors. Johnson and collaborators will develop a new MKID design using manganese doped aluminum, which has been used successfully in another detector technology. They will scale up their existing 23 element design to a 331 element module. They will test this prototype and demonstrate that multiplexing factors of ~1000 are achievable. Finally, they will expand the fabrication pipeline to enable production of more devices. This project will demonstrate the performance of these MKIDs to be comparable to competing technology and demonstrate its potential to advance beyond current technology, especially in terms of scalability for large arrays.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaboration between scientists at Columbia University, Stanford University and Arizona State University to design and build a new type of sensor to revolutionize our ability to map detailed properties of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) radiation - the light left over from the very early universe.

The CMB is light that was generated in the early universe when the density and temperature were many orders of magnitude higher than today. As the universe has expanded, this radiation has remained but its energy has decreased as the wavelength of each CMB photon has been stretched by the expansion. Now, the CMB still fills the universe but is invisible to the human eye and requires sensitive detectors that are able to "see" light at much longer wavelengths. For comparison, the wavelength of light that we see as the color red is approximately 600 nanometers, while the peak wavelength of the CMB today is approximately 1 mm or over 1000x more red.

There have been a number of sensors used to make measurements of the CMB. For example the PLANCK satellite that made the best map so far of the CMB over the entire sky used a combination of bolometers, which are thermal sensors, and radio transistor amplifiers. All of these sensors were cooled to temperatures close to absolute zero (0 degrees Kelvin) to maximize their sensitivity to the CMB which appears as a thermal source with an effective temperature of 2.75 K. A higher signal to noise ratio CMB map than PLANCK is needed to find evidence for even fainter features from the early universe, in particular to detect variations in the polarization of the CMB that were left over from primordial gravitational waves.

The PLANCK satellite had on order of 100 separate pixels or detectors measuring the CMB in nine different wavelength bands or colors on the sky. In comparison, an optical camera in a cell phone typically has 10s or 100s of millions of pixels typically in three colors. More pixels would enable an image with higher signal to noise so the next generation of CMB experiments are all aiming to have cameras with 10s of thousands of pixels instead of 100s of pixels. However, there are many technical challenges to making a large array of pixels that have to work at extremely low temperatures including getting the signals that are detected by the pixels out to a room temperature system that can produce images and store the data for later analysis.

One new technology that is specifically designed to enable large arrays of sensitive detectors is the Kinetic Inductance Detector (KID). A KID is a superconducting resonator that changes its resonant frequency (like the tone of a tuning fork) when different amounts of light are shined on it. An array of resonators, each with a different frequency can be connected to a single readout line and all read out in parallel using a technique called frequency division multiplexing. In this project, we designed an array of KID pixels where each pixel is capable of measuring at least two colors and two polarizations of light from the CMB and the data from the entire array can be sent to a room temperature computer with only two small cables. This technology would enable future CMB experiments to increase the number of pixels by several orders of magnitude. A picture of a test array of these pixels is shown in the attached figure.

Similar superconducting detectors sensitive to a single color are being currently used on ground-based telescopes to make measurements of galaxies and distant galaxy clusters. The new designs developed under this project will make it possible to upgrade these instruments, effectively going from black and white images to the equivalent of full color imaging at these long wavelengths and improve our ability to see the most distant and youngest structures in the universe.
